segments.text: I said, I told you that I traded that, and you can have whatever you can get out of it.
So that's what happened.
He got me that Marine air wing in, and that helped a lot.
What about the B-52s now?
B-52s, I got all of those for 30 hours.
And sure enough, the enemy attacked at 5.30 in the morning.
And to give you an idea about what you learn about the enemy,
how they're going to work, and where they're going to hit you, and how they fight.
You accumulate this knowledge over a period of time.
I ran northeast of town a B-52 strike at 5.30 in the morning when they were attacking, and I aimed that at a VC regiment.
that I knew that was in that area because of my radio intercept capability.
And I knew they were going to be attacking.
And I wanted to coordinate a strike of three B-52s with 108 500 pounders on each B-52
in an area 500 meters wide and 1,500 meters long.
500 meters wide and 1,500 meters long.
I wanted to concentrate all those bombs in there right on that damn regiment.
Must have made just one crater.
Almost.
Well, what happened was I found out later that I had a little captain, 33
Rangers left out of 600 protecting that area.
Started out on it back on the 5th of April with 600 Rangers there and my one little American captain advisor.
Now I'm down to a little American captain and 33 Vietnamese Rangers and they're gonna be hit by this regiment.
Well, that strike
Went in right on time at 5.30.
And lo and behold, I caught only the leading scout elements of this regiment.
And pretty well mutilated them except one little lieutenant with blood.
You know, that concussion is pretty tough from that amount of stuff.
blood coming from his ears and from his nose just kept moving forward and the 33 Rangers, they picked him up.
He gave up.
He was a VC.
Yeah, he was a VC.
So he said to them, you hit the leading elements and the instructions were that everybody in the regiment
go get in those holes because they know that that guy is not going to strike again in the same place.
Now this is at 10 o'clock.
Word came to me, I was airborne in the area, ducking SA-7 missiles, handheld missiles, and 51 caliber.
They were shooting handheld missiles?
Yeah, anything that's flying
But I had to be here.
Were you taking some hits?
Huh?
You must have been taking some hits.
Oh, they knocked down five of them, our Cobra helicopters.
Just cut them out of the sky.
So, American captain called the general, you know, dick around.
You call the guy that can do things.
He said, here's what it is, and they're in those holes.
And this is at 10 o'clock.
I said, Roger, thank you very much.
I said, uh,
Thank you very, very much.
And I looked on my schedule B-52s.
At 10.50 I had another flight coming in, coming in every 55 minutes.
And now, remember, it takes two hours, ordinary time, two hours, and you check with everybody in the world to divert one flight from one place to another of three birds.
Two hours.
To show you how professional our United States Air Force is and the Strategic Air Command, I called in direct and bypassed every guy in the whole chain of the Air Force and said,
Here's the situation.
Call them direct in the air.
And you were talking to Saigon?
I was talking, no, hell, I was talking to the leader of the flight.
And Saigon was monitoring.
And I said, here's the situation.
I got a whole regiment in the holes of strike number such and such this morning.
I want this strike diverted.
using same data, same basis as strike number such and such at 0530.
Roger that.
They had 20 minutes to divert, change the course, came in, dropped, and after it was all over with on the 18th of May,
only 13 members of that whole regiment survived.
13 members out of about 2,100 survived.
Now that's what you have to do to win and you know what one regiment would do against 33 little Rangers and one little American captain.
So
You know, whatever you do, wherever you are, military or otherwise, you can succeed.
It all depends on how bad you want to do it, you know.
Tell me about the rest of the Viet Cong and the rest of the North Vietnamese force in the area now.
Didn't they attack?
Oh hell, they were attacking all the time.
And as I say, it took 30 hours.
There were 55 minutes, three B-52s.
And some, and we extended some a little bit beyond that.
But I interlaced in a 24-hour period 399 sorties of attack air against their tanks.
We knocked the little Vietnamese, took the little old light anti-tank weapon that nobody said was any good, the Law, and they knocked out those guys in town.
I showed you the picture of some of them.
Knocked the guys out in town.
We knocked one out by air, a guy named Gordy Weed, a lieutenant colonel in the United States Air Force, phenomenal pilot.
and ground support guy with what we called an old T-38 trainer.

We had converted some of those to combat and they were carrying bombs and the weather is down and nobody could fly, but he was up with a flight and he came in and he said, we said, there's a tank just outside of the headquarters.
And he said, how much clearance I got from friendlies?
And we said, all you need
And he knocked that tank out about 200 meters from the headquarters there, which could have killed off all my communications.
And then when you lose your communications, you're in a hell of a shape.
Later on, after things subsided, Sir Robert Thompson, advisor to, and a great personal friend of mine, and I love him so much,
Sir Robert Thompson from England was advisor to the President of the United States.
The President sent him over, and the President, he said, the President asked me to ask you to take me into UNLOCK because this will be a very convincing thing to the world that you won the war.
And I did.
I've got some pictures of him in there with the province chief who was a brigadier who had promoted the brigadier.
He was a Marine Corps colonel at the time as province chief.
And then I had to secretly, unbeknownst to the United States, take in the president.
What?
Take in the president of Vietnam into on-law.
He didn't trust his own people.
No, you took President Two in?
Took President Two in, yes, on the 7th of July.
No kidding.
Yes.
But tell me about that.
What kind of person was he?
How was his setting?
I thought he was a phenomenal man.
I thought he was a great, great man, a great presence, dedicated to his country and to very gracious and kind to the United States.
They had tried to get him to relieve this corps commander because everybody thought I ought to have some help.
I didn't need any damn help.
I just needed to be left alone, but this was a

Me commanding that corps, you know, was gonna leak out to the press, which it did, and I denied that I was commanding the corps, and then I went and got this sick lieutenant general and got some pictures of him giving me instructions and me saluting, you know, to prove that I wasn't commanding the corps, but I was all hogwash.
Everybody knew, Abrams knew, Dick Nixon knew, everybody knew I was commanding that damn outfit, and they were trying to get
two, every one of them, went to him to try to get two to relieve this guy.
His name was Min, M-I-N-N-A.
He's now caretaker of St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.
Really?
Yes.
He and his family.
So, uh, I, uh,
Of course, it denied commanding the forces.
I rather enjoyed it.
I mean, hell, it's a goddamn good challenge for me.
You know, it's a difficult task.
I don't think anybody could have done it but me.
That's what Abram said.
And they're probably right.
Because you just don't find anybody...
really in the world today include the goddamn Soviets that had the combat experience that I have and at the levels.
And know how to use air power, which is the key of the whole thing, is firepower.
And how to deliver it and where to deliver it and what the enemy's gonna do.
You gotta know what the enemy's gonna do.
You can't go drop bombs out here and bust up the woods and the enemy's over here.
You gotta know how in the hell to do it.
You've got to have a personal feel of him.
You've got to have your hands on him all the time, and with the electronics capability we have today, you can keep a hand on him if you know how to use him.
That's a, I've got a, and then let me see now, so you left, you left Vietnam just about three or four months after that episode.
Yeah, a very interesting thing, I had my eyes blown away, and I lost this eye totally on the 6th of April from
from rocket fire in Onlock.
And I didn't know it, but it gradually just went out on me.
The shade went down, it was gone.
What it was was a detached retina.
Well, the drawdown over there, we had no ophthalmologist over there.
And I thought, well, maybe this eye is just tired.
It's gone, I can't see it.
I've only got one eye left.
So, it's gone.
So, finally they got a
a hippie type ophthalmologist that had refused the draft and refused this and that and the other.
He had accepted military paid for medical schooling and so on and so forth.
He needed Walter Reed and he didn't want to go to Vietnam and he revolted and they tried his ass and as a result they sentenced him to go to Vietnam.
Oh, what a sentence.
Yeah, and the son of a bitch got in there in August, and the war looked like it was over with at that time, so I said, well, I better go down there.
They said they had to optimize it.
I'll go down, and he takes a look at my eye, and he said, oh, my God, I've got to get you out of here right now.
He said, you've got 90% detached retina, and he said, it's gone.
He said, when did this occur?
I said, well, it started occurring back on the 6th of April.
Well, why didn't you come in?
I said, for what?
I said, nobody here.
And everybody's hollering at me to keep the people out of Saigon.
What the hell am I going to do?
I go do what I'm supposed to do, and to hell with my damned eye.
He said, well, you've got to get to Walter Reed right now.
That's on the afternoon of August 31st.
And by God, believe it or not,
Vietnamese presented me their third highest award the next morning, and I was on the airplane and gone home to Walter Reed.
I stayed in Walter Reed until December the 22nd, and finally got this high back to about 2250.
now General Abrams, Chief of Staff of the Army.
He comes out to see me.
He said, I'm going to send you down to Fort Sam Houston to rest up for a few months.
I said, well, I don't think I've got but one eye left.
I think I'll just get out.
He said, I'll tell you what to do.
You don't tell me.
He said, I'd rather have you with one eye than most people with three.
And he said, you keep your mouth shut, you son of a bitch, but I'm going to give you that tactical army command and promote you in Korea.
You go down there and get rested up.
You sorry bastard.
I said, yes, sir.
I'd land in the goddamn bed.
Still a patch of mine.
Here's Chief of Staff of the Army, and I'll talk to you like that.
Well, we knew each other very well.
So I went down there.
First of July, 1973, word come down, promote him.
Get him to Korea right away.
So we'll do that one tomorrow, okay?
Yeah, but I want to ask you some questions about Vietnam.
Sure.
about just Vietnam in general, and you can stop whenever you want.
If you're getting tired of this, that's okay.
Well, it's about six o'clock.
Oh, okay.
Do you want to stop then?
I can start.
I can answer these questions.
Let's hit them early in the morning.
I'll be glad to answer them though.
It's August 20th, Friday.
And this is the third interview with General Hollingsworth.
And I wanted to start off on something that you said.
And I can't remember if I got it on tape or not.
If we did, we can just edit this out.
And that is that you said, after on lock, that someone said that there's only two fighting generals left in the Army, you and Abrams.
Now, who, when, and where?
That was Ward Just in his book.
And I think, I want to have a copy of that, but I'm not certain.
What book was this one that he wrote?
War Just, I think it was War and People, I believe that was the name of it.
I think you just have to look through the library.
I can't recall it right off.
But that was his comment.
What's your feelings about that comment?
Well, Abrams and I had been considered the two best tank leaders in World War II.
And I don't think either one of us had backed away from the fact that we probably were.
You see?
Yeah.
And that we never talked about it, but I think we enjoyed the fact that others did.
And this came, I guess, from our aggressive attitudes initiative.

intuitive ways of feeling and seeing a problem and I guess some God given attributes in this regard for having a personal feel for people and what it takes to be successful in battle and I'll have to say that I give credit to the big man on high for looking after a very
young fellow who'd had no experience in warfare, wasn't frightened of it, but learned, took advantage of the everyday to learn something and then to apply it.
And I am very grateful for that.
It makes you feel you're destined to do things and do something and that you just continue to go.
That's the reason I just continue to work now and financially I don't have to.
But in my own mind I haven't accomplished anything yet so I'm still looking to accomplish something.
No, no.
Did you ever receive a survey from a brigadier general named Douglas Kinnard, K-I-N-N-A-R-D, asking you to comment about a number of different topics of Vietnam after the war was over?
The survey probably went out in 1975 or so.
Possibly I did, yes.
But you don't remember?
I don't remember specifically.
Well, Kinnard wrote a book called The War Managers, and there is...
There were other two colonels who wrote a book on the Army who were in Vietnam and then retired and wrote a book on the Army.
And for the most part, these books take the Army to task and bring out some real problems, which I'd like to ask you about.
Sure.
These are military men saying that things went wrong and everybody is to blame, but part of it was the military.
And so I'd like to ask you about some of these things.
One is careerism.
As you know, the combat tour of duty, for the most part, was six months.
And a number of these critics say that six months just wasn't long enough to get to know your men, get to know the area that you were in command of, and go out and do a good job.
You should have been in command for a much longer time.
What's your response to that?
I totally agree with that if you're in the United States in training.
But you're supposed to be trained before you go to combat.
And if you're trying to train in combat and getting soldiers killed, that's when General Hollingsworth would relieve you so damn quick it wasn't even funny.
That was no training ground for commanders.
That was a battleground.

and uh and a commander going over to learn to command a battalion in battle and get men killed I wouldn't tolerate that 30 minutes and that's the reason why I was criticized for relieving so many battalion commanders I didn't relieve many I just relieved those who uh that needed to be relieved those who after 30 to 60 days were still doing foolish things and getting men
and his life's in jeopardy, and so he needed to be relieved.
It was in his own best interest that he be relieved of that responsibility.
So, was this typical that you'd have to relieve?
I mean, were there a lot of untrained people?
Because the command was only six months?
Well, it really wasn't six months.
It really wasn't six months.
It depended a lot on the capabilities of the individual.
I can tell you that I can name off 25 or 30 battalion commanders that had 12 months of command over there.

And I'll tell you, it's a devastating thing for a man that was fighting every day, 45 years old, or 40 years old as a lieutenant colonel, fighting every day with 18 and 19-year-olds through the jungle.
And I don't care how physically fit you are or how tough you think you are, it's one hell of a mental and physical battle for a 40-year-old.
I requested that the Army provide the 1st Infantry Division, and General DePue did the same thing, that we have 30-year-old battalion commanders.
And the Chief of Staff of the Army came back and said, the Army cannot meet your requirements.
And I thought to myself, here you are conducting a peacetime promotion and career officer program in a war zone.
And this makes no sense to anybody.
A good commander should have been left over there.

A good captain, company commander, should have been left over there until he commanded the division if the war lasted that long enough and he was physically and mentally fit and promote him every six months if necessary depending on his capabilities.
That's what they did to me during the war and there's no reason why you shouldn't have done that over there.
There was no such thing as a career when I was in World War II.
And the same thing in Korea.
So there is what Kennerly is probably talking about, these people are talking about, that it's just wrong as hell to run a peacetime situation in a war.
In other words, the idea of giving a man a year tour of duty in Vietnam, you're against.
Do you think that the man should stay there for the duration and instead of trying to run it like...
Like part of his career, it should be run as a war.
As a war, absolutely.
And if he's a captain and he's doing great things and doing a magnificent job taking objectives, destroying the enemy's capability and saving his soldiers' lives, after six months, promote him.
After six months more, promote him if he's doing a good job.
At the same time, if he isn't, get rid of him.
I got rid of them, but we had no promotion authority.
Oh, none at all.
None at all.
So that was a bad aspect of management of that conflict.
And it hurt the capability of the units.
I spent 15 months
in the first division going day and night and I was 40 some odd years old I guess.

Now there's another thing that I'm wondering about when we had the most number of troops there in 1969 although we had 560 or so thousand troops there we only had 80,000 troops that were in direct combat
We had a hell of a lot of troops there that were in supply.
Why?
This is a much higher ratio than the Second World War.
Well, again, it gets back to running a peacetime situation.
They even had the inspector general teams over there coming around inspecting the units as if you were in the United States.
What the hell kind of business is that?
In a wartime situation, I flew out of battle one day back to entertain the inspector generals who had been in the division.
But I never noted one damn one of them up in the battalions that were in contact anywhere.
But it had up our logistics people and administrative people tied up in knots back there with the inspector general team.
eight or ten colonels that nobody knew what the hell to do with that was over there getting their months off in Vietnam and their headquarters and going back.
The other aspect of this thing had to do with the number of personnel that were involved in a civilian
in the cords group, rural development group, the province advisors, and their teams were all involved in this.
I think they counted those in the non-combat area along with all the supply people and the huge headquarters that you had.
It's a very interesting thing, even in a combat division,
small percentage of people get in combat.
I think it's too heavy in our army.
I have never been against delivering ice cream to soldiers on a battle area, but I think it's the sort of thing you can get along without.

Do you think, that's another one of the criticisms, that there were a number of supply generals who would say that our troops have never been treated so well in a battle area, our troops, they can have movies, they can have this, they can have, when they have R&R, they can go to really nice places, and this is war, and did you witness
how well, I mean, the idea of trying to give a man out in the field one hot meal a day, which was policy.
What'd you think about those things, being a World War II veteran?
Well, I, of course, went through different kind of conditions.
I got no objection to it, as long as it doesn't interfere with our overall mission of
fighting the war.
Did it interfere?
I don't think it did.
Oh, good.
As far as I'm concerned, it didn't.
And also, I want to assure you that never in the history of warfare in the history of the world have soldiers, sailors, and airmen, Marines, ever received such phenomenal support.
as they received during the Vietnam conflict.
It's a result of a great fluency on the part of our way of life, and I'm afraid we have
pushed ourselves into this soft requirement area.
We know that we can get along without them because we did during World War II and to a large degree during the Korea conflict.
We've brought a lot of this on.
This is a reflection of our society?
Of our society.
It's just a pure and simple reflection of it.
Now there has been some statements that a number of officers in Vietnam went there to get their ticket punched, and I'm sure that you've heard that.
before.
They wanted that on their record because it certainly helped their careers in promotion.
Did you have examples of, or do you have examples of that?
Were there people like that that you met?
If I had any, if I knew about them, I wouldn't accept them as a commander, as battalion commanders.
The 1st Infantry Division being the oldest division in the United States and also
being of such great pride, and we say in the First Division, setting the example for the rest of the Army.
We were very selective about who comes to that division in combat, and we turned down hundreds of officers that tried to get in that division, including general officers.

In fact, the matter is, one time when there was going to be a division commander change, the division commander at that time and myself turned thumbs down on fourteen different generals coming to that division.
No kidding?
Absolutely.
You had the power to do that?
We did it.
When they sent a general out with orders?
They wouldn't send him out.
They'd send his name over.
With a service record?
Yeah.
And you'd look through there and you'd say yes or no?
I said no.
Was this typical?
No.
I didn't think so.
No, no.
How'd you get away with it?
The division commander had more to say about it than I did.
He just showed me the courtesy of asking me my views.
How did he get away with it?
Because a commander-in-chief, Comus McVie, asked him.
Now you may not get that done anywhere except unless you got a close relationship between the division commander and the senior commander in the field.
And there wasn't anything wrong with these officers except their battle experience didn't permit them, we felt, to serve in the first division.
So I'll use that as an example.
say to you that the first division, when you're in combat, as we were, you accept what you want and turn down what you don't want, particularly in the grades of lieutenant colonel and above.

another aspect of the war concerning officers, and that is that there's a study done comparing the percentage of officers to enlisted men in World War II Korea and Vietnam, and the study found that twice as high a percentage of officers were in Vietnam as the other wars, and that there were more generals per troops than at any other time in American history.
Why?
Did it help
Well, it goes back to something I mentioned a little earlier.
Fluency and what you're going to do in a way of support for the soldier in the field requires people to do it.
And secondly, never before in any war that I participated in have we had
teams of officers primarily at each province and each district in the country trying to manipulate the mayor and the town council to
get them to bring pressure to bear to get rid of VC in the area and also to assist the regional forces and the popular forces to do that.
You see, you had Vietnamese divisions, combat forces like we have, and then you had regional forces, RF forces, that's another group,
And then you had the popular forces, which was small groups down in there.
Well, all those had to be officered and supervised, so this takes a hell of a lot of people to do it.
I'd say three times the effort that you would normally consider necessary, and that took a lot of people.
There are more general officers today.
Again, our society and what you have to go through demands that.
During World War II, we had no NATO.
We had no military advisory groups in every country in the world.
We had no JCS, where you got 2,000 today.
We're almost all officers.
A high percentage of general is in there.
You had no Department of Defense, which is another three or four thousand.
You had no officers involved in equal opportunity.
You had no officers involved in human rights.
You can run down, you had no insurance officers.
You had no legal officers.
You had no one looking after retired personnel.
You had no one involved in community relations.
You had no one running the Little Leagues and all the Boy Scouts and the Girl Scouts and all that sort of thing.
But our society had more or less looked to the military to do that.
And somebody, to get it done, you got to come up with somebody to do it.
And so I can clearly understand
the awesome requirements that's placed on the military, and you find, again, more colonels, more generals in headquarters.
Enlisted men are private.
Doesn't contribute a hell of a lot at the cabinet level, does he?
Private.
that we just recruited off the street out here?
No, he's about 25 or 30 years away from that.
So, in other words, what you're saying is that the government is giving the military expanding responsibilities and bureaucracies, and therefore they need someone to lead them.
And the staffs of the United States Senate and the House of Representatives have gone up by more than 1,000%.
Why?
Because of requirements for more of this and more of that and a better analysis of what we're doing than we've ever done before, and you've got to have somebody to do it.
And that's just what we run into.
Okay, now, some people say that...

One problem with expanding the number of officers in Vietnam is that sooner or later, some of the army, as you know, had to lower requirements to get some officers and to get such a number, and the result was that you got an occasional bad apple, somebody like
if it wasn't for the fact of decreasing standards now.
What do you say about that?
What did you think of the junior officers that you worked with, or could you select these two?
We had an unpublished policy, I guess, at that time of meeting numbers.

And if it's a policy of meeting numbers, the fellas, for example, at the artillery school and graduating second lieutenants from OCS for the artillery, they may not agree with it and you may have one or two colonels resign and get out, I mean retire and get out because they don't like meeting numbers.
Generally speaking, I don't think anyone does in the Army at meeting numbered requirements.
But there were people who graduated as second lieutenants who should not have been.
And they were sent to combat.
And many of them failed.
Many of them got relieved and sent out before they really failed from the standpoint of losing, loss of life for someone.
Some, unfortunately, may have committed errors that cost lives and that's it.
thing that happens in battle that you try to avoid at all costs.
What do you do?
Do you go short on these people or do you take a chance?
With me, it's either quality or nothing.
I'm supposed to have 35 officers in a battalion of 500 or 600 men.
I'd rather have 15 officers of high quality because I've got the ingenuity and experience and know-how to maximize that 15's capability and overcome the shortage of the 20 that I refuse to accept.
But we had some there that shouldn't have been there.
No question about it.
But on the other hand, let's look at it this way.

Out of probably some 30,000 to 40,000 second lieutenants, first lieutenants that served in that war over eight years, one bad apple out of 25,000 to 30,000 had one hell of a phenomenal damn record, isn't it?
One hell of a phenomenal record.

So something must have happened over there with the commanders for those that did show up over there that weren't adequately trained or weren't properly motivated or that slipped through the system to meet quotas.
Somebody must have done a hell of a job over there, didn't they?
And I think that's what...
really happened.

Okay now what about the enlisted man the one-year tour of duty for the enlisted man did you did you agree with having the one-year tour of duty or did you like the officers would you have thought that duration of the war was a better way to go about it?
Under the conditions in which they were operating climatically and the type of enemy that you were fighting and the type of war that you're fighting I think
I think one year was all right for these, was enough for these young men.
I would say that for 90% of the officers, but there's somewhere between 10 and 25% of the officers that I would have kept over there, and I say, as long as he's fiddly and mentally sound and fit,
I think he should have been allowed to go home every once in a while to see his family.
I stayed away from my family three years during World War II.
